bibl.title: Letter fragment from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 8, [1890]

div1.p: Lazear writes that he is still in Germany and comments on the German army.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 8, [1890]
div1.p:
I left Strassburg on Monday
morning and walked that day as
far as Bühl about eight miles
from Baden-Baden. In the morning
I walked over the hills to Baden
and met Norris there. He had
come up by rail. We spent the
rest of the morning there walking
around and seeing the sights.
It is a very beautiful place
and beautifully situated.
At noon Norris started for Heidel-
berg by rail and I went off on
foot taking in the old castle
of Baden on the way. I reached
Rostatt last night. It is a walled
and fortified town full of
soldiers. By the way; as I was
leaving Bühl I saw seven companys
of artillery on the march. One of
them had stayed all night at Bühl
the bugle woke me up at six o'clock.
The Germans keep up an enormous
army and they keep them in fine training.
I dropped pedestrianism at Rostatt
for the time being and rode here
by rail stopping for three hours
at Karlsruhe. I did this because
the the country there was not
especially interesting and I
thought it better to put the time
I have on the best parts of the
Rhine. I must stay here a day
or two to get my linen washed
and then my walking shoes
resoled, and then, on again.

In speaking of Miss Pratt you
talk as though I had been very
attentive to her and that it was
necessary to break the news
gently that she seemed to like
Harry Orr. The truth is I was never
any more than decently polite
to her and often not that and
I never called on her but once
in my life. She is an extremely
agreable girl but I am not
a subject for condolence this
time.

I sat up until quite late last night
reading the New York papers that you
sent me. I found four of them
here and I have not finished them
yet. I found a great deal that
was interesting I still think that
the New York Times is the best paper
in the world. Nothing in London or
Paris can come up to it.

Karl Karlsruhe where I stopped yesterday
is quite a pretty place. It is layed out
wheel fashion like Washington. It
is the capital of the Grand-duchy of
Baden and has a palace and many
government buildings and an art
gallery.

I have not yet had time to see much
of Heidelberg but it seems to be
very interesting and it is beautifully
situated.

I have only a week and two days
before I sail. I have ordered my letters
sent to Amsterdam. Altogether I
think my vacation has been very
profitable.
